results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mel F. Nichols, Frank Coffey, Winifred Lade, John Maynard and Department of Information

results.title: Royal tour of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Begins with the Queen landing at Tullamarine Airport and parading through the city in a car. Massive crowds greet her, the city is decorated in red,white and blue in her honour. This is followed by scenes at night with similar, illuminated decorations.

The next day she opens Parliament in the morning, where she gives a speech, before going to the MCG to meet with thousands of ex-servicemen.

On return from Mt. Gambier she visits the Flemington Race Course and Kooyong Tennis Club. A horse race is named in her honour and she congratulates the winning jockey.

At the Shrine of Rememberance, the queen makes a speech and opens the new forecourt.

Meanwhile, the Duke of Wellington inspects a naval base and views a parade.

A garden party is held in honour of the Queen at Government House.

The Queen and Phillip then briefly visit rural Victorian towns on a train.

Phillip is then shown being greeted by ‘wacky’ students at Melbourne University and visiting a science laboratory.

At the MCG, thousands of school students perform dance and gymnastic routines for the Queen.

After travelling to more country towns, where she is greeted by their excited populace, she returns to Melbourne for a final parade in the city.

At Mildura, she is presented with dried fruit and then flies away from Victoria on the Royal plane.

Good titles/’The End’.

results.title: On the land (ii)
results.brief_description: Montage of colourful shots including a streetscape, livestock and grapepicking. Attractive illustrated title. Sound consists solely of a theme song. The music is upbeat, cheesey and evocative of television programmes of the 1970s and 1980s. Good countdown at begining, some numbers written as words, ie ‘six’ not ‘6’.

results.title: Melbourne (no. 3)
results.brief_description: Film features quite general shots of Melbourne in the summer. This includes footage of the Great Ocean Road (including panoramas), a busy suburban pool and St. Kilda Beach. These sequences have a great, nostalgic ‘good time’ vibe to them, which is aided in part by the high-contrast film stock. There is also footage of one of Melbourne’s Gardens (possibly the Botanic), including blooming flowers and people looking at them. Nice shots of man burning leaves followed by the sun breaking through smoke haze and trees in garden. Two shots include views of St. Paul’s Cathederal and the Forum Theatre from the Yarra. Nice, Black and White ‘The End’.

results.title: Fat pigs are out
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Jack Keane and Tony Doogood
results.brief_description:
Film follows a farmer as he foolishes fatens his pigs, only to discover on market day that ‘Fat pigs are out!’. He is then taken to an abattoir and shown the difference between fatty pork and the lean pork that the ‘modern housewife’ now demands.

Comical light-hearted tone throughout. Poor acting and dialogue. Good illustrated titles and ‘The End’.

results.title: The Argentine ant
results.brief_description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.
results.description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.

results.title: Police horses: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters
results.brief_description:
Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters

results.title: Goodness - it's milk!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, promotes the dairy industry by proclaiming the benefits of drinking milk.

The film opens with some lovely footage of a couple exploring the Blue Dandenongs, including a milkbar with signs for ‘Peter’s Ice-Cream’, ‘Herald’, and ‘Four ‘n’ Twenty Pies’, where they order two tall glasses of milk.

The film then shows scenes of schoolchildren, a patient and nurse in a hospital and a domestic kitchen, while the narrator describes the health benefits of milk. The film finishes with footage of the dairy industry, from the farm to industrial pasteurising and bottling processes, and finally home delivery.

results.title: Archival prints
results.brief_description:
1. The Herringbone Milking Shed - Details the ‘new’ Herringbone Milking Shed, which can improve dramatically the speed in which cows can be milked. Good shots of previous cow-milking techniques, featuring nice colour and framing. Amusing stop-frame animation of how the shed works using toy cows.

With Herringbone Shed, 54 cows can be milked in 45 minutes, pre-mechanised milking could only manage 8 cows per hour. 6 minutes.

  1. Living Like Pigs - Begins with a comical example of how not to keep pigs and then gives numerous examples of how to keep pigs correctly. This includes footage of early piggery automation techniques, as well as more traditional pig care solutions. Contains many shots of pigs drinking milk in different types of pig pens. Nice colour and framing throughout. Good ‘The End’.

  2. Exit T.B - Largely about the importance of Tuberculosis eradication in Victoria. Shows the test undertaken to determine whether a cow has T.B and then what occures to the cow if it does (it is killed). Gives examples of different parts of a cow once infected by T.B. Then goes to show various milk products that are exported overseas and the importance of eradicating T.B so that more products can be exported. Good titles/’The End’.

  3. Poultry Industry Review - Begins with chicks being hatched and sorted into ‘males’ and ‘females’. Shows how battery hens are kept and then focsuses on an egg packing plant and the technology behind it. Good footage of lots of different machinery mainly concerned with extracting the raw egg from the shell. Shows how ‘eating’ chickens are prepared for sale and dressed, then focuses on turkeys and ducks. Fantastic shots of hundreds of Turkeys in a pen and an odd turkey de-feathering machine. Well-edited montage at end featuring chickens, eggs, ducks and turkeys. Good ‘The End’.
